Walk, a generative algorithm

Julian Weis

Intention

We all take unique walks through life. Viewed together, these walks weave a tapestry. The joy, the pain, the remarkable, and the boring, which are sometimes all-important in a given moment, fade into beauty when taken together. This work shows the tapestry weaved by the walks of simple automata, a model of the tapestry we weave together as humans. In viewing this work, one might achieve a sort of detachment from the individual agents. If one would like, one might also achieve a sort of detachment from one’s own story, seeing instead the beauty of the tapestry that we weave together, as we all try to navigate ourselves and the others around us. This detachment can facilitate understanding and compassion for others and self.

Process

In this work, the automata take center stage. I set up their tendencies, but then I let go. For example, large compositional shapes are not explicitly programmed; the automata generate these shapes themselves. The automata often change location, color, size, and sometimes even the rule by which they move. Some automata move according to complex and dynamic representations of distance. The automata choose their colors from the Flora, Locks, bridges, and signs from a walk along the Upstate New York Erie Canal, and also, sometimes, from a painted rock garden outside of a hospital.

Research

I am interested in visualizing algorithms that involve automata. I love to see how different automata interact. I am as inspired by reading fiction - for example, the interactions of Chekhov’s characters - as I am by studying data structures. Many have noted that complex behavior can emerge from automata following simple rules, and the goal of my research is to understand how these rules, under additional constraints, translate to a visual experience. I take a statistical perspective, because it allows for automata whose behavior can easily become complex.
